title: 106_s149
content: The "Child Safety Lock Act of 1999" may be cited as the Act. It pertains to child safety locks. The term 'locking device' refers to a mechanism on a firearm designed to prevent discharge without deactivating it with a key or combination lock. The text discusses the requirement for a locking device on firearms to prevent unauthorized discharge, which must be approved by a licensed firearms manufacturer. The amendment to Section 922 of title 18, United States Code, requires licensed manufacturers, importers, or dealers to provide a locking device when selling a handgun, with exceptions for government entities. The amendment to Section 922 of title 18, United States Code mandates licensed firearm sellers to include a locking device when selling a handgun, with exceptions for government entities. Additionally, the amendment allows for the transfer or possession of firearms by law enforcement officers and rail police officers for law enforcement purposes. The effective date of this amendment is 180 days after the enactment of the Act. The section clarifies that no civil liability can be imposed on firearms dealers for compliance with the amendments made by the Act. Evidence of compliance with the amendments is not admissible in court proceedings, except for enforcement actions. Governmental penalties can still be imposed under section 924(p) of title 18, United States Code. Section 924(p) of title 18, United States Code allows for penalties related to failure to comply with section 922(y). Amendments to section 924 include the ability to suspend or revoke licenses and impose civil penalties for violations of section 922(y)(1) by licensees. The Secretary may impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 for violations of section 922(y)(1) by licensees, with review available as outlined in section 923(f). The suspension or revocation of a license or civil penalty does not prevent other administrative remedies.
